dialogues.text: MERYL, wearing a stylish robe, sits at the kitchen table sipping coffee. On the table in front of her lies a parce TRUMAN enters and glances at the gift.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: What‘s that?

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: It’s a surprise. TRUMAN unwraps the parcel - an expensive-looking set. of exercise sweats. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: (eager for his response) Well, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: They're... (the merest hesitation) perfect. Thank you. Truman returns Meryl’s kiss.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: (handing him the sweat top) Try it on. Truman pulls the top over his head. As he does so, a clos shot focuses on the manufacturer’s name.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: I thought you could wear them when you do your exercises. (afterthought) Pre-shrunk. And they breathe. EXT. TRUMAN'S HOUSE. DAY. Wearing a business suit, briefcase in hand, TRUMAN emerge from his pleasant, Victorian-inspired, picket-fenced hous into an idyllic suburban street of similarly picturesque homes. A neighbor, SPENCER, is taking in trashcans, whistling a tune. Spencer breaks off abruptly as Truman approaches his car. His license plate reads, “Seahaven - Nice Place To Live".

dialogues.speaker: SPENCER
dialogues.text: Morning, Truman.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Morning, Spencer. And in case I don't see you, good afternoon, good evening and good night. Spencer’s dog, PLUTO, bounds happily over to Truman.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (petting the dog) Hey, Pluto. Truman exchanges a polite nod with the WASHINGTON’s, an African-American family across the street. MR. WASHINGTON is farewelled by his WIFE and CHILD. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Truman is about to climb into his car when he is distract by a high-pitched whistling sound. Suddenly, a large spherical glass object falls from the sky and lands with deafening crash on the street, several yards from his car The startled Truman looks to Spencer but he has abruptly disappeared inside his house with Pluto. Mrs. Washington Washington Junior have also made themselves scarce. Truman investigates. Amidst a sea of shattered glass are remains of a light mechanism. He looks around him but the street is deserted. He checks that all the surrounding street lights are accounted for, even though the fallen fixture is far larger. He looks up into the sky but there is no plane in sight. With some effort, Truman picks up what's left of the crumpled light loads it into the trunk. A label on the light fixture rea "SIRIUS (9 Canis Major)". As he drives away, we hear the sound of his car radio.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Another glorious morning in Seahaven, folks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMAN makes his way along the streets of Seahaven past a series of quaint, pastel-shaded cottages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A high-angle reveals an anonymous mid-sized town built ar a small, pretty bay. A cluster of high-rise buildings sta at the water’s edge overlooking a marina. Surrounding the commercial center lie neatly arranged suburbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pausing at a traffic light along a seaside road, TRUMAN l through a curious wooden arch to the beach and ocean beyo The sight triggers a memory in his head.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYBACK
dialogues.text: Unlike a conventional flashback, the scene in his memory appears to be playing on a television screen. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “THE TRUMAN SHOW"

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FOUR-YEAR-OLD TRUMAN runs towards a bluff on the beach. The boy's father, KIRK, late-~thirties, beer bottle in ha flirts with TWO TEENAGE GIRLS at the shoreline. Suddenly, the father remembers his son. He looks anxiously around. The sight of the boy at the far end of the beach causes h to drop his bottle in the sand and run to Truman. The boy is near the top of the cliff before his agitated father comes within earshot.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: {out of breath, clutching his side) Truman! Truman! Stop! Truman turns from his perch and waves happily down to his father. But the smile quickly vanishes when he registers anger and distress on his father’s face.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Come down now! His father's unnatural anxiety makes the next bay even mo tantalizing. The boy considers defying his father. He put his hand on the rock above him to stretch up and sneak a at the other side. One good stretch would do it.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: (reading Truman’s mind, enraged) No!

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Why? What’s there?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: (unconvincing) Nothing. It’s...it's dangerous. (trace of desperation) Come down, now! Please! Truman is suddenly aware that the hundreds of other BEACHGOERS have stopped their activities te stare at him. Reluctantly, he starts to retrace his steps down the rock When he finally jumps to the sand, his father embraces hi and leads him away.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: I told you to stay close. Don’t ever ieave my sight again. (pause) You’ve got to know your limitations. You could’ve fallen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through his car window, TRUMAN buys a cup of coffee froma streetside VENDOR.

dialogues.speaker: VENDOR
dialogues.text: How are ya, Truman?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (placing his fingers to his pulse) Vital signs are good. He pulls into a parking space and sips on the coffee. As .drinks, he becomes aware of a school bell summoning chil to class in the adjacent Elementary School. The image prompts another childhood memory.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYBACK
dialogues.text: Once again, the flashback appears to be Playing ona television screen. : SEVEN-YEAR-OLD TRUMAN sits in the middle row of an Elemen School classroom surrounded by twenty-or-so other weil- scrubbed, uniformed YOUNGSTERS. MARLON, the boy next to Truman, is on his feet under the scrutiny of a kindly Nor Rockwell-style SCHOOL MISTRESS.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL MISTRESS
dialogues.text: What do you want to do when you grow up, Marlon?

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: I want to be an entrepreneur like my dad.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL MISTRESS
dialogues.text: (impressed) Tell the class what an "entrepreneur" does, Marlon.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: He makes a lot of money, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL MISTRESS
dialogues.text: A good one does, Marlon. (looking in her purse, hamming it up) Perhaps I'll be coming to you for a loan one of these days. The CLASS titters. Marlon sits down and winks to Truman. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8 10 “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 6

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL MISTRESS
dialogues.text: What about you, Truman? Truman rises to his feet, gathering his nerve.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: I want to be an explorer {with reverence) ..like Magellan. The School Mistress smiles benevolently.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL MISTRESS
dialogues.text: (slightly condescending) I‘m afraid no one’s going to pay you to do that, Truman. You might have to find something a little more practical. (glancing to a pulldown wall map behind her head) Besides, you're too late. There’s really nothing left to explore. The class roars with laughter as the crestfallen Truman t his seat.

dialogues.text: (into receiver) ..-okay, okay, let’s call it what it is... I’m not going to lie to you...life insurance is death insurance...you’ve just got to ask yourself two questions... one, in the event of your death, will anyone experience financial loss?...and two, do you care? A CLERK drops a large reference book on Truman’s desk. Truman checks the spine - “MARITIME ACCIDENTS”.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (into receiver) Hold on will you? (to Clerk, referring to the book) This is no good. Lumps all maritime accidents together. I need drownings as a separate category. The Clerk shrugs, returns the book to his cart and contin his rounds.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (returning to his call) ++-just think about what I’ve been saying and let me...hello?... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: {lowering his voice) Can you connect me with directory inquiries in Fiji? A CO-WORKER suddenly pokes his head over the neigboring c

dialogues.text: What do you know, Truman?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (embarrassed, mouthing the word) --Can’t talk. (waving off his neighbor, pretending to be on a business call) I'm sorry, Ma’am. If he’s in a coma, he’s probably uninsurable. The Co-Worker disappears back into his own cubicle.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: {lowering his voice again) Hello, operator...yes, Fiji...Do you have a listing for a Lauren Garland...? {pause) ..-nothing listed?...what about a Sylvia Garland...“S” for Sylvia...nothing? dialogues.text: Behind a deli counter, TYRONE, fifties, is having his hai brushed by a YOUNGER MAN. Tyrone has anticipated Truman’s order and has already begun preparing a meatball and mozzarella sandwic an Italian roll. Truman gazes at the sandwich skillfully under construction, pained by his own predictability.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: (nauseatingly cheerful) How’s it going, Truman? . (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (deadpan) Not bad. I just won the State Lottery.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: (not listening to Truman’s reply) Good. Good.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Tyrone, what if I said I didn’t want meatball today?

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: (not missing a beat, passing Truman his wrapped sandwich) I'd ask for identification. Truman forces a half-smile and exits.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: See you tomorrow, Truman.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: You can count on it.

dialogues.text: “with a mutiny but half-repressed and starvation imminent, he pressed southward till he found the long-hoped-for straits...” Truman is interrupted by a TRANSIENT in a wheelchair. dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (into receiver) ..-this isn’t about insurance, this is about the great variable - when will Geath occur? Could be a week, a month, a year. The prospect on the other end, unimpressed with Truman's pitch, hangs up. Truman's supervisor, LAWRENCE, younger t Truman by several years, sharper suit, sharper haircut, appears around the corner of the cubicle.

dialogues.text: (handing Truman some documentation) Hey, Burbank, I’ve got a prospect in Welles Park I need you to close. Truman’s face falls. He stares out of his third floor win at the hazy skyline of a nearby island across the bay.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (referring to the island) Welles Park on Harbor Island?

dialogues.text: (sarcastic) You know another one?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN

Mustering all his nerve, he marches into the Seahaven terminal and buys a token for the ferry Out of his hearing, TWO FERRY WORKERS observe Truman’s agitated behavior.

dialogues.text: I got a feeling this is the day.

Unaware of the scrutiny, Truman passes through the turnstiles with a herd of TOURI and COMMUTERS. He makes his way across the terminal, but abruptly pulls up at the gangway. As the other PASSENGERS impatiently brush past him onto t boat, Truman remains frozen to the spot, mesmerized by th scummy water rising and falling beneath the dock. dialogues.text: (shouting above the wind) Let’s go further, daddy! Let’s go further!

dialogues.speaker: KIRK
dialogues.text: (shouting back) It’s getting rough, Truman.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (entreating his father) Please!... Kirk shakes his head ruefully and indulges his son by hea towards the gathering storm clouds on the horizon.

She is being taunted by TWO YOUNG THUGS. She attempts to ignore the youths by concentrating on the book on her lap.

dialogues.speaker: YOUTH 1
dialogues.text: (to woman) You wanna read to me? His companion smirks.

dialogues.speaker: YOUTH 1
dialogues.text: (more insistent) You wanna read to me? The boy reaches over and snatches the novel from her gras

dialogues.text: {menacing) My friend asked you a question. The woman picks up her bag in a reflex and holds it to he She looks about for assistance, briefly catching Truman's The youths also look in Truman's direction, staring him d

dialogues.text: (reaching for the book) Please... The boy returns the book to the woman, but before doing s rips out the last page from the novel and stuffs it in hi shirt pocket.

dialogues.speaker: YOUTH 2
dialogues.text: Now you‘re gonna have to ask me how it ends. _ One of the youths grabs the woman, dragging her toward surrounding woods.

dialogues.text: 22 23 24  "THE TRUMAN SHOW" as

dialogues.text: Gee, that's great. Looking over Truman’s shoulder, Meryl notices a small, un patch of grass missed by Truman in one of his passes,

dialogues.text: See here, this is us. (sliding his finger around the other side of the ball) All the way round here, Fiji. You can’t get any further away before you start coming back. dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMAN and MARLON wander along the empty bridge, retrievi the golf balls. Marion goes to say something to the disconsolate Truman, is momentarily distracted. He raises his hand to his ear. Truman places another of the balls in the bucket.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: Truman, you know, I did think about moving away one time.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: {interest piqued) Yeah, what happened?

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: I figured, what’s the point? I knew I’d just be taking my problems with me. Once the kids came along, it made me look at Seahaven with new eyes. (gazing out at the lights of Seahaven) I realized, what the hell could be better than this? (putting a hand on Truman’s shoulder) I'm telling you. What you really need is someone to carry on the “Burbank” name.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: Trust me. Marlon picks up the last ball at the mouth of the upturne cone. The ball is white.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: (checking the ball) You win. They approach Truman’s car. Truman opens the trunk to deposit their humble golfing equipment. Inside are the remains of the fallen light fixture.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (referring to the light) You really think it could’ve dropped off an airliner? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 28 29 30 “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 20

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: (unimpressed) Sure. It’s halogen. Shame it didn’t hit you - you could’ve sued, (quickly changing the subject) You coming for a drink?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: I can’t tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the POV of the lighthouse’s lantern room, we observe TRUMAN sitting on the beach staring out to sea. Closer on Truman. He has a portable tape recorder slung o his shoulder and points a corded microphone at the surf. watch Truman‘s impassive face as he makes the recording o the lapping waves. The lamp from the lighthouse occasiona falls upon Truman.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYBACK
dialogues.text: As always, the flashback appears to play on a television The sky is black with storm clouds. Gale force winds lash rain into the faces of SEVEN-YEAR-OLD TRUMAN and his fath KIRK. As Kirk stands up to get his bearings, a freak gust wind catches the sail. The boom whips across the stern an strikes Kirk flush in the head, knocking him overboard. Truman, wearing the sole lifejacket, desperately reaches his father. He momentarily has hold of his father's hand when Kirk is abruptly dragged beneath the surface.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (crying out) Daddy!!...Daddy!!... His cries go unanswered. Seven-year-old Truman finds hims alone - the storm abruptly passed, the wind suddenly drop the water stilled. The frightened Truman examines the ring he holds in his o hand - his father’s ring - wrenched from his finger in Truman's fight to keep him afloat.  31 32 33

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BEACH. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A close up of TRUMAN from KIRK’S RING that Truman now wea Then, from the lighthouse POV, we observe Truman get to h feet and walk towards the dark water. He stands at the water’s edge.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (shouting at the surf) I'm sorry, Dad! I’m sorry! As if in reply, a tongue of lightning flashes across the distant skyline, followed by a growl of thunder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TwO OLD WOMEN, seventies, sit beside each other on a sofa looking directly into camera as they talk.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN 1
dialogues.text: (playing amateur psychiatrist) It left him with more than his obvious fear of the water.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN 2
dialogues.text: He was never the same curious little boy again.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN 1
dialogues.text: Half the women I know named their children after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMAN is forced to leg it through a sudden rain shower t his car. From Truman’s point-of-view, the shower appears quite nor However, viewed from a distance, we see that the shower i extremely localized, encircling only him, as if a small c is directly above his head, tracking his progress. As Truman crosses the parking lot, the shower crosses wit him. Sensing something amiss, Truman dances back and fort across the street, intrigued by the curious phenomenon. H hums a few bars of “Singin’ In The Rain”. The rain becomes heavier, covering a wider area. Truman r the remaining distance to his car.  34

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drenched TRUMAN enters to find MERYL in the unfinishe nursery, comparing wallpaper samples. Meryl wears a robe, glimpse of black negligee beneath.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: Where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (wringing out his jacket) I’ve been thinking--

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: (rolling her eyes) Oh, God.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (ignoring the reaction) --I figure we could scrape together eight thousand.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Every time you and Marlon--

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: --We could bum around the world for a year on that.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: And then what, Truman? We’d be back to . where we were five years ago. You’re talking like a teenager.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Maybe I feel like a teenager.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: We're mortgaged to the eyeballs, Truman. There's the car payments. Are we just going to walk away from our financial obligations? Truman, still dripping on the floor, holds Meryl by the a He talks excitedly to her the way we imagine he did when were courting.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: It'd be an adventure. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 23

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: I thought we were going to try for a baby. Isn't that enough of an adventure?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: That can wait. I want to get away. See some of the world. Explore. Meryl gives a derisive laugh.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: You want to be an explorer? You don’t even have a passport, Truman. I bet you don’t even know how to get one, The words sting. Truman turns away. Seeing the pain she’s caused, she changes tack.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: This’1l pass. Everybody thinks like this now and then. (making an attempt at seduction) Come to bed.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: I think I’m going to stay up for a while. 35 INT. AN OFFICE BUILDING SOMEWHERE - RECEPTION. NIGHT. In the reception area of an office building, TWO UNIFORME GUARDS Grink coffee.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD 1
dialogues.text: How can they have a child?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD 2
dialogues.text: It’s not gonna be his, you idiot.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD 1
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD 2
dialogues.text: You think she’d go through with it? GUARD i Sure she would.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD 2
dialogues.text: {reassessing his own opinion) Guess I always thought they'd adopt.  36 37 38 39 40

dialogues.speaker: "THE TRUMAN SHOW" 24
dialogues.text: EXT. TRUMAN’S STREET. DAWN. 36 There is something peculiar about the way the sun rises o Seahaven Island - the light appears in an arc that's slig too perfect and well-defined. INT. TRUMAN’S BEDROOM. MORNING. 37 In front of his bedroom window, TRUMAN, wearing his new sweats, performs an exercise routine of his own invention He counts off the exercises to himself - cheating as he d so. He counts five leg-lifts for every two he completes.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: --Five... (two leg-lifts later) Ten...fifteen...two more makes twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A middle-aged MARRIED COUPLE in identical matching sweats repeat the same eccentric exercises in perfect sync, as i they were in a class led by Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMAN climbs into the car and switches on the radio. He down the street.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Another glorious morning in Seahaven, folks. Don't forget to buckle up-- Truman mutters to himself as is his custom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMAN emerges from the parking lot and as usual stops at newspaper stand. He picks up a glossy magazine and flips through the cosmetic ads, surreptitiously tearing a pair EYES from one of the pages. He returns the magazine to th rack. As usual, the NEWSPAPER VENDOR fails to intervene. Truman begins his daily pilgrimage to work through the ru hour pedestrian traffic. As he enters the street leading to his office, he glimpse HOMELESS MAN reflected in the window of a parked car. Truman, spellbound by the man, suddenly wheels around to him. The Homeless Man, late- fifties, more well-groomed a (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 40 "THE TRUMAN SHOW" 2s

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: well-fed than the average vagrant, has a serene smile on face. The Homeless Man places his hand ever so gently on Truman cheek. Truman makes no effort to withdraw. He is transfix by the man’s eyes. He appears to recognize him.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (almost to himself, mouthing the word) Dad... Suddenly an ELEGANT WOMAN SHOPPER walking a small WIENER and a BUSINESS EXECUTIVE carrying a briefcase, walking in opposite directions along the sidewalk, grab the Homeless Man. One under each arm, lifting the Homeless Man off the ground, they start to whisk the bewildered derelict down street.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (calling out) Stop! Stop!! Truman begins to give chase. However, the shopper and the businessman are surprisingly fleet-footed. Even more surprising as Truman embarks on the pursuit is the behavi of the PEDESTRIANS and COMMUTERS. They appear to part for the fleeing trio then close ranks in front of him. Is it accidental, or are the pedestrians working together, runn interference?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (shouting at the pedestrians) Outta the way! Outta the way! They are escaping. Truman finally breaks through the pack, bowling over seve of the pedestrians in the process. Just as he gets within reach of the shopper and the businessman, a bus suddenly screeches to a halt beside the abductors, doors already o The Woman Shopper and the Executive bundle the Homeless M onto the bus. Truman lurches after them, but he is met by the bus doors, closing sharply in his face.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (to BUS DRIVER) Hey, stop! Stop the bus!! Truman thumps against the doors, but the BUS DRIVER ignor his cries and the bus roars away. The other PASSENGERS in the bus, apparently oblivious to the incident, keep stari straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Truman continues to give chase when a taxi appears out of nowhere and cuts in front of him, blocking his path. When recovers, the bus has disappeared. The mysterious crowd o pedestrians has also dissolved as if it never existed. Retracing his steps, head reeling, wondering if he could imagined the whole incident, Truman discovers that the Wo Shopper has left her WIENER DOG behind. The dog wanders aimlessly on the pavement, its leash trailing behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMAN paces impatiently in the living room of his Mother cramped, fussy, doilyed little house full of Burbank fami memorabilia - a cluster of framed photographs is dominate one of his FATHER trimmed with a black ribbon. A toilet flushes and Truman’s MOTHER finally emerges from the next room, She presents something of a contradiction. Although she walks with the aid of a “walker”, she is actually a well- preserved sixty. She wears a glamorous nightgown and a fu head of bleached-blonde hair.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (kissing Mother on the cheek) How are you, Mother?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Well, I made it through another night.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: How's your hip?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Oh, just so. Truman supports Mother.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: You know. surprises aren’t good for me. You should really call before you come over, dear.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: I’ve got something to tell you. You’d better sit down. Truman helps her into an overstuffed armchair. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: "THE TRUMAN SHOW" a7 41

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: You look very pale, Truman. Are you taking your vitamin D’s?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (exasperated) I spend half my life out in the sun, Mother, why would I need vitamin D?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: I feel certain my condition runs in the family. (putting the back of her hand dramatically to her forehead) Can‘t this wait, dear? He kneels beside her.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: No, I’m afraid it can’t. Truman takes a deep breath as he prepares to give her the

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: I know this is going to sound insane, Mother, but...I saw Dad today on Lancaster Circle. He’s alive. Mother smiles condescendingly.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: It doesn’t sound insane, Truman. I swear I see him ten times a week--in a hundred faces. I almost hugged a perfect stranger in the salon last Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: It was Dad, I swear, dressed like a homeless man. And you know what else was really strange? A businessman and a woman with a little dog appeared from nowhere and forced him onto a bus.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: About time they started cleaning up the trash Downtown. We don't want to end up like the rest of the country.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (excited) They never found Dad's body - maybe somehow-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: ~-Darling--

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (already doubting himself) I’m telling you, if it wasn’t him, it was his twin. Did Dad have a brother?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: You know he was an only child, like you. {placing a comforting arm around him) I know how bad you feel about what happened--sailing into that storm. But I don't blame you, Truman. I never have. Mother kisses Truman on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (referring to her platinum blonde hair) I was thinking about going lighter. What do you think? Truman regards his Mother. Her hair is already impossibly INT. TRUMAN’S BASEMENT. DUSK. 42 The basement is cluttered with junk - ships in bottles, a train track without trains, an oxygen mask, a stringless guitar, many abandoned projects. The basement is dimly li by a single, naked bulb. TRUMAN looks over his shoulder before opening a large walk-in cupboard. On the cupboard door is a wall map of the Pacific Ocean - the Fiji Island are carefully circled. Amongst the many tools and househo implements inside the cupboard is a trunk under a dusty canvas sheet. He pulls the trunk into the room, unfastens the lock and opens the lid. Inside, mementoes from his youth. A "HOW TO SAIL” book, a stack of “GREAT EXPLORERS” magazines, and beneath it all, garment in a drycleaning bag. Truman carefully lifts up t plastic to reveal a young woman's cardigan sweater. He pu the cardigan to his nose and takes in its scent. Footsteps. Truman hastily drops the cardigan in the trunk and shuts the lid. MERYL's legs appear on the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: What’re you doing down here? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 29

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (turning attention to an upturned mower on the basement floor) Fixing the mower. (matter-of-fact) I saw my father today.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (suspicious) How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: Your mother called. You shouldn’t upset her like that. Meryl's response takes the wind out of Truman's sails.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: What did you want?

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: I made macaroni.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: I'm not hungry. Meryl nods, not at all convinced.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: We really ought to toss that mower out. Get one of those new Elk Rotaries. Truman does not reply. After an uncomfortable pause, she turns back up the stairs. Truman waits a moment before re-opening the trunk. He removes the cardigan and holds it up, reminiscing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MOTHER, DAUGHTER about 12, and a BABY in a highchair st into camera.

dialogues.speaker: DAUGHTER
dialogues.text: What's he doing?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: They removed all physical trace of her but they couldn’t erase the memory. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAUGHTER
dialogues.text: The memory of who?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (finger to lips) Shhh!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COLLEGE CAMPUS
dialogues.text: Once again the images appear to be playing on a televisio On the steps of a typical college campus, TRUMAN, 21, ina college band uniform, participates in a football pep rall MARLON, 21, a member of the football team, and MERYL, 21, cheerleader, are nearby. Truman observes an ethereal-look young woman walk by - LAUREN. PLAYBACK - INT. DANCEHALL. NIGHT. 44a At a college dance, TRUMAN dances with MERYL. LAUREN danc by with a PARTNER of her own. However, Truman only has ey for Lauren. Suddenly, she is escorted from the dance floo

dialogues.speaker: PLAYBACK
dialogues.text: TRUMAN almost trips off the curb as he waves to LAUREN, riding towards him on a bicycle. However, she rides right with her nose in the air, not even acknowledging his pres - Truman puzzled by her change of heart. The montage ends at a scene in a college library.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYBACK
dialogues.text: In the school library, TRUMAN, 21, sits with MARLON, 21, wife-to-be, MERYL, 21, doing a final cram for a test. The STUDENTS begin to pack up their books. Meryl gives Truman peck on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: Come on, Truman. Haven't you studied enough?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: I still want to look over a couple of things. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: (punching Truman in a chummy way on the arm, referring to Truman’s books) Take the "C" average. That's what I do. Truman looks up from his books. The library is almost deserted. He spies a GIRL's hand around the table divider Truman musters the nerve to poke his head over the divide finds LAUREN on the other side, buried in a book.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Konichi-wa, Lauren looks blank.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (referring to the Japanese text in front of her) You take Japanese.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: (quickly closing the book) Oh, yes. ‘TRUMAN (glancing to the name carefully written on the front of the book) Lauren, right?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: {as if unaware of her own name) That's right. Lauren.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: {extending his hand) I‘m Truman, Truman Burbank--

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: --I’m not allowed to talk to you. Truman is not surprised.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (resigned) It’s okay. I probably wouldn’t talk to me either.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: (softening) I'm sorry. It’s not up to me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 32

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (crestfallen) You have a boyfriend? Of course you do. Lauren looks about her, unsure.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: No...I, er.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: {hopeful once again) No? Really? Good, I mean, I thought possibly a pizza. How about Friday?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Saturday? Lauren looks around the almost-deserted library.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Actually, I'm free Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Now.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Right now? We’ve got finals tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: If we don't go now, it won’t happen. Truman hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: (impatient, looking anxiously around) Well, what do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: {closing his books, still a little uncertain) I think I've studied enough.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYBACK
dialogues.text: LAUREN, taking TRUMAN by the hand, runs down various stre and paths through the campus. She occasionally pauses and looks about her, often changing direction or looking up a streetlights and the towers of houses along their route, if trying to elude an unseen pursuer.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The excited and apprehensive Truman runs with her althoug is unsure exactly who, or what, they are running from. The further they get from the campus, the higher, wider a less effective the coverage of the scene - some camera an are even partially obscured.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYBACK
dialogues.text: TRUMAN and LAUREN eventually cross an empty highway on th of town. They run over the dunes onto a strangely deserted beach a down to the water's edge under a hyper-real full moon. Lauren throws off her cardigan and hitches up her skirt, wading out into the inviting water without another though Truman stares down, transfixed by the shimmering water.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: (splashing) It's beautiful! What are you waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (nervous) I...I can’t. Lauren suddenly stops splashing.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: That’s right. Oh, God, I’m sorry. She wades out of the water.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: {confused) Why, Lauren? You've got nothing to be sorry about? Lauren, dripping wet, stands beside Truman at the shoreli meets his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: My name's not Lauren. It’s Sylvia. Truman looks into her eyes and believes her. Truman wipes the water from her face, then leans forward and gently ki her lips. She kisses him back.  48 49

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a quiet bar room, a WAITRESS explains her viewpoint to BARMAN. A PATRON on a barstool eavesdrops.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Don’t you get it? She was willing to lose him, lose everything, if it meant he could find himself. (registering the barman’s blank look) Never mind. You wouldn’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYBACK
dialogues.text: As we return to Truman's reminiscence, TRUMAN and SYLVIA she is now called throughout the remainder of the movie) on the sand at the water's edge. With great delicacy, Tru traces the outline of her nose with his finger, at the sa time inhaling her scent. Sylvia looks nervously around he Truman goes to say something but Sylvia hushes him.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: They're coming. Any minute.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (looking around the deserted beach) Who?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: They're going to stop me talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (confused) There's no one here.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (looking over her shoulder nervously) Just listen. You remember when you were a little boy, you stood up in class and said you wanted to be an explorer like Magellan--

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (incredulous) --How Go you know about that?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: --And your teacher said, “You're too late, Truman. There's nothing left to explore.” .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “THE TRUMAN SEOW" 35

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Were you there--how do you know?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: --It doesn’t matter. Everybody knows about it. They know everything you do. The point is, you got scared.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: {looking over her shoulder, increasingly nervous) You must listen. Everybody’s pretending, Truman. She points to the sky and scoops up the sea water at thei

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: You think this is real? It’s all for you. A show. (frustrated, raving) The eyes are everywhere. They're watching you - right now. ( Suddenly a car's headlights come bouncing over the dune . The car roars across the beach towards the couple.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (scared) I told you, Truman! The car skids to a stop and a large MAN, 40ish, with a sh red hair, jumps from the car. The man yanks the frightene Sylvia to her feet, causing her cardigan to fall to the g

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (to Sylvia, oddly sympathetic) Lauren, sweetheart, not again. Get in the car! Truman jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Hey, who the hell are you?!

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I’m her father!

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: We weren't doing anything. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49 50 51 “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 36

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: He’s not my father! He’s just saying that! Does he look anything like me?!

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Come on, Sweetheart. The Man gently, but firmly, pushes Sylvia towards his car resists. Truman crosses to them.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: I'll take care of her! . The Man takes Truman aside and whispers in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (whispered, out of Sylvia‘s earshot) Schizophrenia. She has episodes. Doubts start crowding into Truman’s head. SYLVIA . (calling out from the car Don’t listen to him, Truman. I'm telling you the truth!

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: {getting into the car) Don’t bother! We're moving to...Fiji - the Fiji Islands! This place has done something to her head.

dialogues.speaker: INT. A DIMLY-LIT ROOM SOMEWHERE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: CHRISTOF stares intently into camera. Beside him is his assistant, CHLOE, an androgenous-looking young woman. She too stares into camera.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: At least he didn't say “New York City".

dialogues.speaker: PLAYBACK
dialogues.text: TRUMAN stares after the car as it roars away. He turns ba toward the ocean where his attention is caught by an obje lying on the sand - Sylvia’s cardigan.  52 53 54 55 56

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRUMAN'S BASEMENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: TRUMAN carefully places the cardigan back into the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOTHER, DAUGHTER and BABY stare into camera.

dialogues.speaker: DAUGHTER
dialogues.text: But why didn’t he just follow her to Fiji?

dialogues.text: Marlon~-

dialogues.text: (startled) --Truman, what are you doing here? Truman looks nervously around him. Even the STORE OWNER’s friendly nod from behind the counter is cause for suspici in Truman’s mind.

dialogues.text: (whisper) I’ve got to talk to you.

dialogues.text: I’m onto something, Marlon ~ something big.

dialogues.text: (bemused) No. Truman, if this is another one of your fantasies...

dialogues.text: (taking an interest in th monument ) : It looks so small.

dialogues.text: Everybody off. We've got a problem. The relieved passengers hurriedly exit until Truman is th only one remaining on the bus. The Bus Driver looks almos sorry for Truman who sits resolutely in his seat - the hi of a tear of frustration in his eyes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: I predict the next four cars will be a white Honda Civic, a blue and white Dodge Dart with the front hubcap missing, a Volkswagon Beetle with a dented fender and a motorcycle. dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: There's the Honda...the Dodge...here comes the dented Beetle... Meryl’s attention wavers. Truman tightens his grip.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Look! Following the VW is a school bus.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: (mocking) Where’s the motorcycle? Truman is momentarily disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Don’t you want to know how I did that? A motorcycle putters by. Meryl turns and walks back to th house. He hurries after her.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: I invited Marlon and Rita for a barbeque Sunday. I thought I’d make my potato salad. Remind me--

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: I won't be here Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: ~--we need more charcoal. TRUMAN . Are you listening to a word I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: You're upset because you want to go to Fiji. Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Truman is puzzled by her conciliatory tone.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: Okay, do it. Get it out of your system. Save for a few months and go. There. Happy now? I'm going to take a shower. She turns away.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (catching her wrist) Let's go now.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: What?! Despite her protests, Truman drags Meryl towards his car. ‘TRUMAN (as he shoves her into the car) I’m ready to go now. Why wait? INT. TRUMAN’S CAR. DAY. 90 TRUMAN holds MERYL‘s wrist to stop her exiting the car an accelerates out of the driveway in reverse without lookin almost running over PLUTO the dog and SPENCER with his garbage can. Truman starts circling a gazebo at the center of a roundabout, faster and faster.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Where shall we go? Where shall we go? Spontaneity is what it's all about. Forget Fiji. We can't very well drive to Fiji, can we? What about Atlantic City?

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: (trying to mask her anxiety) You hate gambling.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: That’s right. I do, don’t I?

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: So why do you want to go?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Because I never have. That’s why you go places, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: Truman, I think I'm going to throw up. Truman roars off down the street.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Me too. Almost immediately, Truman encounters a traffic snarl.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: {a manic edge to his voice) So much traffic, this time of day. Does that strike you as peculiar? Without warning, Truman suddenly dives down a sidestreet. his move is anticipated. At the end of the street, a pack cars suddenly appears. Other vehicles fill the gap behind

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (to Meryl, marveling) Blocked at every turn. Beautifully’ synchronized, don’t you agree?

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: (incredulous) You blaming me for the traffic?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Should I? Truman reverses suddenly and makes a U-turn.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: You're right. We could be stuck here for hours. Could be like this all the way to Atlantic City. Let’s go back. I’m sorry. I don’t know what got into me. Truman starts heading back the way they came, the roadway relatively free of traffic.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: Would you please slow down, Truman? Truman floors the car. The car flies past their house.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: Truman, that was our house! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: I've changed my mind again. What’s New Orleans like this time of year? Mardi Gras. Or let’s just see where the road takes us.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: (pleading) Let me out, Truman. You’re not right in the head. You want to destroy yourself, you do it on your own!

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (eerily calm) I think I'd like a little company. As he speeds erratically, Truman glances at the streets o either side of the main road where he discovers a distinc lack of moving traffic.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (to the anxious Meryl at. his side) Look, Meryl. No cars! I don’t run into traffic. The traffic follows me around. (excited by his discovery) We‘re in a moving pack, don’t you see?

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. TRUMAN'S CAR
dialogues.text: But TRUMAN's clear path is short-lived. He is forced to s once again behind a line of other cars at a bridge.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (to Meryl) It’s hard to go places, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: {looking up ahead at an overturned car) There's been an accident, Truman.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Uhuh. There's no accident. It's just more stalling. Truman floors the car again and swerves into the oncoming lane. He roars along the bridge on the wrong side of the road. Near the end of the bridge, a distraught MOTORIST dashes into the middle of the road, waving his arms. Trum slams on the brakes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Truman, it's a child. I've got to help -

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (hardly glancing to the boy) He'll be fine. _ Truman roars on, almost bowling over the concerned moto

dialogues.text: Truman, I took the "hypocrite" oath!

dialogues.text: They roar pass an illuminated sign - "FOREST FIRE WARNING Extreme Danger".

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: Truman, what about that sign?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: I'm sure they're just exaggerating. Suddenly, a 20 foot high wall of flame shoots across the roadway in front of them - as if someone flicked on a gas switch.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: What about that - do you believe that?! TRUMAN experiences his first moment of doubt. He looks to the terrified MERYL, then closes his eyes tightly and accelerates through the fire wall. He is startled to find that they have emerged on the other side, singed but unscathed. . (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: However, the open road in front of them now disturbs Trum for a different reason - its sheer lack of anything unusu Signs along the road advertise motels and give directions other destinations - "I-6211 - 2 miles“, "Notel Motel - P Color TV". dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: So what do we do for money when we get to New Orleans?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN

dialogues.text: So we just eat into our savings, is that the idea? I'd better call your mother when we get there. She'll be worried sick - I don't know how she's going to take this. Truman appears very unsure of himself.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER

dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.text: You’re lucky he’s not glowing, Ma‘am. Next time we’ll have to file charges. Meryl joins TRUMAN at the kitchen table. Truman applauds ironically.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: Let me get you some help, Truman. You're not well.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (ignoring her medical advice) Why do you want to have a child with me? You can’t stand me.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: That‘’s not true. Meryl picks up a package and holds it to camera.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: Why don’t I make you some of this new Mococoa Drink? All natural. Cocoa beans from the upper slopes of Mount Nicaragua. No artificial sweeteners--

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (incredulous) --What the hell are you talking about?!

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: I’ve tasted other cocoas. This is the best. Truman rises from the table and backs her around the room (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: What the hell has that got to do with anything? Tell me what’s happening?!

dialogues.text: (frightened but remaining poised) You're having a nervous breakdown, that's what's happening.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: {backing her up against the kitchen bench) You're part of this, aren't you?! Meryl grabs the "Chef's-Mate" from the counter to protect herself. She points the potato peeler at him.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: Truman, you’re scaring me! Truman looks into her eyes and, with surprising swiftness grabs her wrist and disarms her.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: No, you’re scaring me, Meryl! Truman grabs Meryl and turns the Chef's Mate on her. He stares wildly about him.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Stop this now. I’11 do it. I swear.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: Do something... Upon hearing her remark, Truman‘s eyes widen. Sensing tha she too is addressing a third person, he jerks her head around to read her face.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: {wild-eyed) Who were you talking to?!

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: (incredulous) You’re the one talking to the walls!

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: No. You said, “Do something.” Who were you talking to? Tell me! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: Truman, stop it! Suddenly, the front door chimes.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Right on time. Cops must be telepathic. Truman grabs his peeler and marches Meryl down the hallwa the front door. The doorbell chimes a second and third ti more insistently.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN"
dialogues.text: (shouting through the closed door) Stay where you are!

dialogues.speaker: MARLON, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Truman? It’s me, Marlon. TI need to talk to you. Truman flinches. He was so convinced it would be the poli He takes a step back against the hallway wall. Before he decide what to do, MARLON has opened the unlocked front d to be confronted with the sight of Truman holding the pee to Meryl’s throat. Marion locks eyes with Truman. Sizing up the situation, h slowly but decisively removes the peeler from Truman’s ha Meryl wrenches herself free from Truman’s now limp grasp collapses into Marlon’s arms, sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: MERYL
dialogues.text: (distraught) How can anyone expect me to carry on under these conditions? This is...unprofessional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARLON and TRUMAN, both nursing bottles of beer, sit on t end of the unfinished bridge.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: I don't know what to think, Marlon. Maybe I'm going out of my mind, but I get the feeling that the world revolves around me somehow.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: It’s a lot of world for one man. You sure that’s not wishful thinking, you wishing you'd made something more of yourself? (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MARLON (cont'd) Christ, Truman, who hasn‘t sat on the John and had an imaginary interview on "Seahaven Tonight"? Who hasn‘t wanted to be somebody?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: This is different. Everybody seems to be in on it. Marlon looks around as if drawing inspiration from somewh in the night.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON

I always liked that, because whatever the answer was-- Truman chimes in, nodding fondly at the-memory.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: --we were right together and we were wrong together.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: The only night either of us ever spent in jail, we spent together and I wet myself but you never told anyone. I was best man at your wedding and my brother was best man at my wedding and you didn’t talk to me for a month over that and I didn’t blame you because you’ve been more of a brother to me than he’s ever been. Truman is slowly coming around - Marlon’s speech from the heart soothing away his pain.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: I know things haven't worked out for either of us like we used to sit up on Monroe Avenue all night and dream they would. We all let opportunities pass us by. None of us asks for the dance as often as we should. I know that feeling when it’s like everything's slipping away and you don’t want to believe it so you look for answers someplace else. But, well, the point is, I would gladly step in front of traffic for you.  98 99

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTOF stares intently into camera, holding his distinc earpiece to his head. Beside him, his ever-present assist CHLOE.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (hushed tones) And the last thing I'd ever do is lie to you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: (staring into Truman’s eyes) And the last thing I’d ever do is lie to you. (pause) Think about it, Truman, if everybody’s in on it, I’d have to be in on it too. I’m not in on it, because there is no it.

dialogues.text: So what are you saying, Marlon, the whole thing has been in my head--?

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: (meeting his gaze) Not the whole thing, Truman. You were right about one thing.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN -
dialogues.text: What‘s that?

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: The thing that started all of this. TRUMAN looks up in the direction of MARLON’s gaze. A FIGU stands at the end of the freeway - a homeless man. It is father, KIRK.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: Yes, he survived somehow. He's got quite a story to tell. Marlon helps Truman to his feet - Truman still transfixed the figure.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: Go to him.

dialogues.text: I never stopped believing.

dialogues.text: (gazing at the ring, then up to Truman’s face) Thank you...my son.

dialogues.text: And wide... SIMEON looks to his director.

dialogues.text: Close up?

dialogues.text: All those years, wasted.

dialogues.text: We have a lot of years ahead.

dialogues.text: And fade up music...now go in close... As a tight two-shot of father and son fills the screen, t orchestra swells with triumphant music.

dialogues.text: FATHER and SON remain in the embrace. Over Truman’s shoul we see a flash of guilt flicker across MARLON’s face.

dialogues.text: CHRISTOF, emotionally drained by the events, slumps in hi chair. CHLOE rests a supportive hand on his shoulder. The of the network, MOSES, a man in his seventies, enters wit young assistant, ROMAN - their faces full of admiration.

dialogues.text: Well done. Well done, everyone.

dialogues.text: A YOUNG WOMAN reclines on a bed, her back against the wal Propped up on her knees is a book. However, she’s not reading but staring straight into camera - a look of prof sadness on her face, It is SYLVIA. From her point-of-view, we see a portable television set table at the foot of the bed. On the television is a live picture of TRUMAN - the first time we have seen him on a television screen. He is sitti at his kitchen table, unaware of the cameras recording hi The shot is static. dialogues.text: At one point, a sponsor‘s border appears on the screen, tastefully framing the “action”, with the message, “MOCOC Cocoa beans from the upper slopes of Mount Nicaragua”. "The Truman Show" them music begins. The camera cranes up and over the Hollywood sign, the flatlands of Burbank stretching into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (VO)
dialogues.text: From the network that never sleeps - broadcasting live and unedited 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, around the globe... During this continuous aerial shot, overlapping scenes fr Truman’s life appear in chronological order, from infancy adolescence and finally adulthood. Photographs of leading CAST MEMBERS also appear in individual frames.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (VO)
dialogues.text: ...with Hannah Gill as Meryl Burbank, Louis Coltrane as Marlon, Alanis Montclair as Mother, re-introducing Walter Moore as her husband, Kirk... The music swells as the camera approaches a mammoth struc the base of the mountains - a dome so vast it dwarfs ever around it. At the top of the dome is a huge painting of T face encircled by satellite dishes - inside each dish is letter spelling out, T-H-E T-R-U-M-A-N S-H-O-W - a banner proclaims, "30th Great Year".

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (VO)
dialogues.text: ...and Truman Burbank as Himself, taped in the world's largest studio, one of only two man-made structures visible from space, comes the longest running documentary soap opera in history, now in its 30th great year - "The Truman Show"! The camera rushes towards the outside wall of the giganti bathed in sunlight. When we emerge on the other side, it night. The camera cranes up from a calm, moonlit ocean to nightsky above. As we near the crescent-shaped moon, we discover that it is actually a window overlooking Seahave Standing in the "crater" window is the suited CHRISTOF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulling back from the window we reveal an INTERVIEWER, mi forties, conservative suit and hair. A large television shows a live picture of Truman, immersed in his book.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: I'm your host, Mike Michaelson, coming to you live from the Lunar Room on the 121st story of the OmniCam Ecosphere, 2800 feet above Seahaven Island. Tonight, a special edition of “Tru Talk”, the forum where we discuss and analyze recent events on the show. We are honored to bring you a rare and exclusive interview with the show's conceiver, creator, tele- visionary, the Man-In-The-Moon himself-- Christof. (referring to the image of Truman between them) I remind viewers that as "The Truman Show" is a living history, it is our practice to keep the image of Truman on screen at all times. A TITLE APPEARS: Due to the live and unedited nature of t program, viewer discretion is advised. The Interviewer turns to Christof.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Welcome.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: The catalyst for the recent dramatic events was of course Truman's father, Kirk, and his infiltration onto the show. Before we discuss that, it’s worth reminding viewers that this isn’t the first time someone from the outside world has tried to reach Truman.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: We have had our close calls in the past. Behind the two men, the constantly playing image of Truma engrossed in his book is relegated to a window on the scr  106 107 108 “TRE TRUMAN SHOW" 73
