dialogues.text: TRUMAN, 7, is opening presents under the tree - KIRK and MOTHER proudly looking on.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Who can forget the infamous “Christmas Present” incident in the seventh season? Suddenly, a small MAN bursts from a large, Christmas parc Kirk and the man grapple on the floor in front of the stu seven-year-old. Kirk drags him away.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYBACK
dialogues.text: As the adult TRUMAN makes his way to work, a PARACHUTIST from the sky into the main street, only yards behind him.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: And only last summer “Billie Blackbird” made his third attempt, leaping from a lighting gantry. The parachutist is dressed entirely in black with a messa emblazoned on his chest, "TRUMAN, YOU'RE ON TV." COMMUTER grab the man and drag him away - Truman blissfully unawar the incident.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (dismissive) These people have their own agendas. Many just want to be on television themselves.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYBACK
dialogues.text: The encounter between TRUMAN and the homeless KIRK is replayed up to the point where Kirk is bundled onto the b

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Of course, there has never been anything to compare with this - the first time an intruder has been a former cast member--

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: --a dead one at that.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: --and certainly the first time that an intruder has been rewarded with a starring role. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: so 108

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 108 INTERVIEWER (cont'd) (gushing) I really must congratulate you on writing Kirk back in. A master stroke.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: {feigning modesty) Since Kirk started this whole crisis in Truman’s life, I came to the conclusion that he was the only one who could end it.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: I understand he's hardly had a life of his own since he left the show. How did you convince him--was it the opportunity to be close to Truman again?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: That and a fat, new contract.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: How do you intend to explain his twenty- two year absence?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Amnesia.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: (impressed, nodding in agreement) Of course. The Interviewer consults his notes.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Let's talk ratings. “Truman” has always enjoyed top ten status but the huge surge over the last few days--how do you hope to sustain that audience now that Truman appears to have reconciled himself?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: As you know ratings have never been our primary goal. I imagine we'll lose those voyeurs only interested in witnessing Truman’s latest torment. However, I’m certain that our core audience will remain loyal.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: But recent events have been so dramatic, it does raise the perennial question. What keeps us watching this one man twenty-four hours a day - eating, (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 108 “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 75

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: INTERVIEWER (cont'd) sleeping, working, sitting for hours in contemplation?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: It has to be the reality. During this segment, we cut to a cross-section of VIEWERS the WAITRESS and BARMAN in the bar, the TWO OLD WOMEN on their sofa, the TWO SECURITY GUARDS and the MAN in the ba listening to Christof’s theories on their viewing habits.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: We've become tired of watching actors give us phony emotions, bored with pyrotechnics and special effects. While the world he inhabits is counterfeit, there’s nothing fake about Truman himself. No scripts, no cue cards. It’s not always Shakespeare but it’s genuine. That’s how he can support an entire channel.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: A window onto the human condition?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: I prefer to think of it as a mirror. At that moment, Truman - still live on the screen - unwittingly punctuates the pretentious remark with a belc Christof and the Interviewer try not to notice.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Not only does he give us a glimpse of the truth, he gives us a glimpse of ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: But how do you account for the popularity of those eight hours a day when Truman sleeps?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: We find many viewers leave him on all night for comfort. Haven’t you ever watched your child or your lover sleep?

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Let's go to some of those viewers’ calls. The Interviewer presses a blinking, illuminated button on desk's high-tech phone terminal. During this segment, various windows open on the screen advertising products f the "Truman" catalogue. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Charlotte, North Carolina, for Christof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered, from speaker phone) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: You're on, Caller. Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: MALE CALLER 1
dialogues.text: Christof, it’s a great honor to speak with you.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MALE CALLER 1
dialogues.text: How much of a strain has the last few days placed on the actors?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Working on “Truman” has always been a huge commitment for an actor, not just in terms of separation from friends and family, but since Truman essentially drives the plot, it is a never-ending improvisation - witness Marlon'’s extraordinary performance in the recent "Father And Son Reunion" episode.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: {cutting off the call) Are we talking Emmies?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Certainly a nomination.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Of course, Truman has always been very much in on casting.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: As with our own lives, the only people he can’t cast are his family. Otherwise he has final approval, able to elevate an extra into a lead role as was the case with his only real friend, Marlon, or alternatively relegate a star to a bit player. ~ (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 77

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: (pressing another line) Istanbul, Turkey, you’‘re on with master videographer, Christof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christof, I’ve admired your work my whole life, although I can’t say I’ve seen it all.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Who can?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CALLER 1
dialogues.text: Can you settle an argument for me? What’s the longest time Truman has been off-camera?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (trace of pride) In his entire life, forty-two minutes. A technical fault in the twelfth season accounts for most of that time. The remainder generally results from blindspots, in the early days, when Truman would stray out of range of our cameras.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: We should remind viewers that Truman, especially as a child, presented a challenge for the production.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: {turning to the screen) Let me demonstrate with some examples. Footage of TRUMAN as a baby appears on the screen - as a newborn INFANT, held in a pair of anonymous latex-gloved hands, and as a TODDLER, dressed in various baby outfits one occasion looking through the bars of his crib.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: He was curious from birth - premature by two weeks, as if he couldn’t wait to get started.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Of course, his eagerness to leave his mother’s womb also meant he was the one selected. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 78

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (enthusing) In competition with five other unwanted pregnancies - the casting of a show determined by an air date - he was the one who arrived on cue.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Who knew that a show originally meant to last one year - "Bringing Up Baby" - would turn into a "cradle to grave" concept. He is in fact the first child in the world to be legally adopted by a corporation.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: That's correct.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: And the show now generates a yearly income equivalent to the gross national product of a small country.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: People forget it takes the population of an entire country to keep the show running.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: I believe your own shareholding in OmniCam is in the order of--

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: --Why is an artist plagued with these questions? I've never done this for any monetary gain.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: No, of course not. (quickly changing the subject) And since the show runs 24 hours a day with no commercial breaks the staggering profits are all generated from product placement.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Yes, everything you see on the show is for sale - from the actors' wardrobe, food products, to the very homes they live in-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: All products carefully chosen and tested by you for quality and aesthetic value.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: There's nothing on the show I don't use myself.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: And it's all available in the "Truman Show" catalogue. Operators are standing by. Christof nods.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Why do you feel that Truman's never come close to discovering the true nature of his world?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: We accept the reality of the world with which we're presented. As the show expanded, naturally we were forced to manufacture ways to keep Truman in Seahaven - demonstrating that every venture is accompanied by a risk. The SEVEN-YEAR-OLD TRUMAN we have seen in other flashback appears on the screen. Wearing a cowboy outfit, he goes t cross the walkway of a bridge when he is suddenly confron by a savage DOG wearing a spiked collar.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Later, Kirk’s drowning made much of this kind of intervention unnecessary. We freeze on seven-year old Truman's terrified face.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: You've never actually met Truman, yourself. Never thought about doing a cameo -- playing a veterinarian, or a priest, something like that?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: I've been tempted. But I think it's important to retain objectivity. I wouldn't want to get emotionally caught up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: "THE TRUMAN SHOW" i)

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: The Hague for Christof...The Hague?...lost them. (pressing another line) Hollywood, California, you're on “Tru Talk”.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CALLER 2, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How can you say he lives a life like any other?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (sensing the thinly disguised resentment in the Caller’s voice) As the Bard says, "All the world's a stage, and all the men and women merely players." The only difference between Truman and ourselves is that his life is more thoroughly documented. He is confronted with the same obstacles and influences that confront us all. He plays his allotted roles as we all do--

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CALLER 2
dialogues.text: --He’s not a performer. He's a prisoner. The Interviewer goes to cut off the call, but Christof st

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (rising to the challenge) And can you tell me, caller, that you're not a player on the stage of life - playing out your allotted role? He can leave at any time. If his was more than just a vague ambition, if he were absolutely determined to discover the truth, there’s no way we could prevent him. I think what really distresses you, Caller, is that ultimately Truman prefers the comfort of his "cell" as you call it.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CALLER 2
dialogues.text: (as if trying to convince herself, giving herself away) --No, you're wrong! He’ll prove you wrong! He can still do it! The Interviewer hangs up on the caller.  109

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a darkly lit room, we see SYLVIA. It is she who is the confrontational Caller - phone still in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (from the television) We’ve learnt about life as Truman has and, despite the complaints of a minority, it’s been an overwhelmingly positive experience, for Truman and for the viewing public.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Let’s take another call. (pressing a line) London, England you’re on “Tru Talk".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christof? Congratulations on the way you've always handled Truman's "sex"-life - the classical music, soft lighting and so on. But has the recent violence caused a problem for the show’s sponsors?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: The sponsors know the risks going in, although we do try to maintain standards - a level of decorum. For instance, I‘ve never put a camera in the toilet. Still in silhouette, SYLVIA turns down the volume on the television. Focusing on the window on the screen that displays TRUMAN, she comes close to the screen, catching melancholy, saddened by his regression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMAN breathes in the scent of Sylvia’s sweater one last time before reluctantly replacing it in the trunk, togeth with his book, "To The Ends Of The Earth - The Age Of Exploration". For a final time, he regards his unfinished picture of SYLVIA inside - two holes where the eyes shoul be. As he does so, he finds two lost paper cuttings - a p of eyes on the basement floor. He tries them. Ironically they fit - the picture completed. He closes the trunk anyway. With a sense of finality, he fastens the lock.  110 111

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The giant ON-AIR monitor in the control room plays a clos shot of Truman sleeping. CHRISTOF comes close to the monitor and almost touches th screen. As he does so, Truman twitches in his sleep. INT. BATHROOM. MORNING. i111 TRUMAN wipes the mist from the mirror of the bathroom cab and stares into it in a way he has never done before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close up on the giant ON-AIR monitor in the control room. It displays a wide shot of Truman staring into the bathro mirror. We slowly pull back to reveal SIMEON and the other VIDEO OPERATORS sitting at the mixing desks arranged in tiers reminiscent of an auditorium or NASA's Mission Control. Each mixing desk contains a dozen-or-so built-in monitors and is designated with a location such as “Truman's House - Interior", "Truman's Office - Cubicle", "Tyrone's Deli" The operator at each desk, sitting in a swivel chair and wearing the slimmest of heatsets, is responsible for monitoring a particular location. The monitors cover virtually every facet of Truman's life Camera angles from the interior of Truman’s house, his backyard, car, office, the deli he frequents, the seashor to which he is drawn, the unfinished bridge where he golf with Marlon - many of the locations strangely devoid of people. Simeon, seated in the front row of mixing desks, stares b at Truman's image on the monitor, slightly unnerved.

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: (to a nearby COLLEAGUE) Is he looking at us? As if to reassure the technician, Truman begins one of hi familiar monologues. He talks to the mirror as if being interviewed.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: --What are my plans now? Well, next I'm thinking of tackling the Yuba River in an authentic canoe from the Algonquin tribe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 111A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 112 113 114 TRUMAN (cont'd) -- I'm talking about the north fork, a class five rapid - only I'm not going down the Yuba, I'm going up. Do you honestly think for one minute I'd go back to some dreary office to rubber stamp meaningless documents...do you?

dialogues.speaker: MERYL, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: --Truman, you're gonna be late! Truman sighs as he exits the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMAN exchanges a cheery greeting with SPENCER.

dialogues.speaker: SPENCER
dialogues.text: How are ya, Truman?

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Inhale...exhale...same old thing. He waves to the WASHINGTONS across the street. He pets PLUTO the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back at work at the insurance company, TRUMAN sits in his cubicle making another of his cold calls.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: --a forty-two year old woman sitting in the second row at an amateur production of Hamlet, Hamlet's dagger slips from his hand and flies into the audience... A YOUNG WOMAN, carrying a stack of files, catches Truman’ as she passes. VIVIAN. She is faintly reminiscent of Sylv at the same age - even wearing a similar sweater.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (returning to his call) --what I'm saying is, life is a fragile thing. ..hullo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMAN wheels his lawnmower, deliberately averting his ey from the back of the house. Staring out of the kitchen window, a tall glass of iced tea in her hand, MERYL has b (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: anticipating her husband’s appearance. She wears a neckbrace, we sense more as a reminder to Truman than for medical benefit she might derive. Feeling Meryl’s eyes burning into his back, Truman fires the mower and heads directly towards the symbolically unc section of grass. We focus on the errant blades of grass they are severed by the mower - a new Elk Rotary. The law is now uniformly trimmed - Truman's final act of defiance laid to rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTOF stands at a large, specially screened window, silhouetted against the twinkling stars and full moon of hyper-real nightsky. Members of the cast enter the room - principal characters Truman's life - MERYL, MARLON, MOTHER, KIRK, TYRONE, LAWR and the new actress, VIVIAN. They take their places aroun long, oval table for a story conference - Vivian sitting slightly apart from the rest of the cast. We glimpse over Christof’s shoulder at what he sees - the town of Seahaven far below, bathed in moonlight. He comes out of his reverie and joins his cast, sitting at the hea the table. In front of him, a TV "tablet" plays silently showing Truman drinking a glass of milk in his kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (to the assembled cast) First of all, I'd like to welcome Walter back onto the show. (nods in Kirk’s direction) You may have done us more of a favor than you ever imagined. (turning to Meryl, using her real name) Regrettably, I also have to inform you that Hannah has chosen not to renew her contract. All eyes turn to Meryl. She looks at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: I'm sure we can all respect her reasons. Meryl receives a sympathetic squeeze of the hand from her star Marlon, now out of wardrobe, wearing an Armani suit. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: os.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: As you all know, we have already begun to orchestrate her break-up from Truman. (more up-beat) However, on a more optimistic note, I‘m pleased to announce that television’s first on-air conception will still take place. You witnessed the initial contact this morning. (glancing to Vivien, once again using her real name) You all know Claudia from her work in theatre.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: I loved your Ophelia.

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDIA
dialogues.text: Why thank you. The rest of the cast nod politely in Claudia’s direction. CHLOE passes out a bound document to each cast member.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (referring to the documents) This is a copy of Claudia’s back story. Her character’s name is "Vivien". The cast idly flips through the documents, prominently stamped on the cover, "NOT TO BE TAKEN ON SET”.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: We intend to entice Truman into the affair as soon as possible. Claudia will make a pass at the insurance seminar Truman's attending. Details are in your schedules. (pause for effect) I don’t have to tell you how critical the next few weeks will be. This takes us into the next generation. When Truman‘’s child is born, the network will be © switching to a two-channel format to chronicle both lives.

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDIA
dialogues.text: What happens when Truman and the baby are both on camera together?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: There will simply be duplicate coverage. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 115 116 117 118 “TEE TRUMAN SHOW" 86

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDIA
dialogues.text: (mischievous) Let's just hope we don’t have twins.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: (uncharacteristically flippant) When Truman dies do we go back to the single channel? The cast turns in his direction. Christof shoots him a disapproving look. INT. TRUMAN’S BASEMENT. NIGHT. 116 TRUMAN sleeps on a cot bed in his basement - more clutter than usual. A virtual bombsite - dozens of cardboard boxe stacked everywhere. Although he is covered in bedding, hi sock-clad feet stick out of the bed covers. The outline o his body is still clearly visible. He snores quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TWO OLD LADIES have nodded off on their sofa in front the television, their breathing and occasional snores ech those of Truman. In the BAR, the WAITRESS - normally an avid viewer - only glances to the screen as she passes with a tray of drinks The MAN in the bath resignedly lets the water out of the and goes to get out. The MOTHER only occasionally glances to the screen as she feeds her BABY. Her DAUGHTER has her eyes closed, bopping her Walkman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIMEON sits at his control desk, directing the "night-shi He pays scant attention to the big screen, giving his instructions in a lethargic, metronomic manner.

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: ...Ready two. Go to two. An OPERATOR, eating a slice of pizza, presses one of the illuminated buttons on the panel and the camera angle cha to a close shot of Truman’s covered head. The camera stay the blanketed head for a long moment. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 118 “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 87

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: And back to the medium... Another button is pressed and the angle changed. A trace frustration is evident in the control room. Recording a sleeping subject is unrewarding enough without also havin contend with Truman’s recently acquired camera-shyness.

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: ...and wide...

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR
dialogues.text: (aside to Simeon) What a loser.

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: Who cares? Makes life easier for us. He is what he is. At the far end of the control room, one of the large doub opens and CHRISTOF enters, dressed in a smoking jacket. S the Operators subtly straighten in their chairs. Christof not to notice. He is staring intently at the ON-AIR monit

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Why is he in the basement?

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: He moved down there after Meryl packed up and left.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Why wasn't I told? Any unpredictable behavior has to be reported. {returning to the screen) Is that the best shot we can get?

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: What's to see?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: What’s on the ClockCam? The operator punches up the camera hidden inside a broken cuckoo clock. A box obscures the view.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR
dialogues.text: There's an obstruction. Christof watches Truman, a trace of concern in his eyes. CHLOE enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 88

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (referring to the debris in Truman‘s basement) What happened down there?

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: He was tidying up his garbage. (sensing Christof’s concern) I was going to call you. But half-way through, he gave up and fell asleep. Apparently satisfied, Christof turns to an Operator.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: I want to check the set-ups for tomorrow's insurance convention. Reading off the notes in Chloe's folder, the Operator pun a batch of camera angles on smaller preview monitors. The a generic-looking hotel, devoid of actors. A banner in re reads, “Welcome Seahaven Life and Accident”. The Operator looks to Christof for approval and realizes producer's attention has wandered. Christof has wandered down to the front of the room to stand beside the giant O AIR monitor still displaying the sleeping figure of Truma

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Give me a shot from Truman’s ring.

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: He gave it back to his father. Christof nods.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (a trace of concern) Why is he so still? Christof picks up a spare headset from the panel and puts to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Isolate the audio. An operator pushes up an audio fader on the panel. Christ and his colleagues listen to Truman’s steady breathing in their headphones.

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: (shrugs) He's still breathing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 118 119 120 “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Simeon and the Operators nod, reassured that nothing is amiss. Christof is not so easily convinced.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Give me a preview. An ECU on his torso. A camera hidden in the room's lamp zooms in to Truman’s p outline. While the breathing remains steady, the body doe not rise and fall. Christof, still listening to his headphones, detects a faint scratching sound followed by strange thud.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: {anxious, barking a command to Chloe) Phone him. Chloe picks up a phone connected to the desk and dials.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: {anticipating Chloe’s question) Tell him it’s a wrong number. The upstairs phone begins to ring. Truman doesn’t flinch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TWO SECURITY GUARDS are intrigued by Truman’s unanswe phone on their television set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTOF and SIMEON concentrate on another, separate moni playing in fast-rewind, time code in the bottom right-han corner. It is a recording of the night‘s transmission. Simeon pauses on the last on-camera appearance by Truman. They watch Truman, on-screen, switch off the basement lig and climb into the cot bed fully clothed, immediately pul the covers over his head. As the light is switched off, t recording camera automatically switches to night vision. Simeon continues to play at normal speed, now and then scrolling forward in fast-forward mode. Christof suddenly points to the screen.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: There. Freeze...Zoom into the chair... Simeon types the appropriate command. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Enhance. ..there! On the blown-up screen, between a cardboard box and a cha leg, it is barely possible to make out Truman’s hand as h crawls commando-style from beneath the covers and behind cardboard box near the large tool cupboard. Simeon points out an angle of the empty staircase.

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: He hasn't gone up the stairs. He's still in the room. EXT. TRUMAN’S HOUSE. NIGHT. 121 MARLON's car squeals to a halt outside Truman’s house. Hurriedly dressed in jeans and coat over a bare chest, he dashes barefoot up the porch to the front door. He tries doorhandle, pounds on the door and rings the doorbell simultaneously, shouting Truman's name all the while.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: Tru!..Tru!..Earthquake alert...flood! We've gotta get outside onto the street! Tru?! Frustrated, Marlon picks up one of Meryl’s carefully nurt flower pots from beneath the porch window.

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: (shouting a warning) I’m coming in, Tru! Marlon hurls the flower pot through the window. INT. TRUMAN‘S HOUSE - BASEMENT. NIGHT. 122 MARLON switches on the light and clambers down the wooden stairs to the basement. He pushes away the clutter and finally stands at his co-s bedside. He gingerly lifts the covers. Beneath the beddin clothes have been carefully piled to resemble a sleeping figure - socks placed on the end of two tree branches. Buried amongst the clothes is Truman’s portable tape reco Marlon places the recorder next to his ear. The cassette the sound of TRUMAN BREATHING.  123 124

dialogues.speaker: 124A
dialogues.text: 125 “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTOF stares, wide-eyed, at the image on the On-Air monitor of MARLON.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Find him, Marlon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARLON starts frantically pushing aside the clutter, send Truman's model ships and other hobbies crashing to the fl Eliminating all other possible hiding places, he confront Truman's tool closet, the wall map of the Fiji Islands st hanging on the door. Marlon rips open the door and is hit with a shaft of light - moonlight. The top of the closet has been removed and a crude tunnel containing a ladder heads almost directly upwards to the outside of the house. The bottom of the closet is ankle d with dirt. Embedded in the tunnel wall-is Meryl's Chef's Mate - Truman's digging implement. EXT. TRUMAN'S HOUSE. NIGHT. 124a MARLON's head pops up outside the house. Unable to help himself, Marlon looks directly into a wide shot camera concealed in a streetlight.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Marlon, don’t look at the camera! Say something!

dialogues.speaker: MARLON
dialogues.text: (to streetlight, stunned, breaking the fourth wall) What? He’s gone!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: {to Simeon, quiet but firm) Cut transmission. Simeon hesitates, unsure if he has heard correctly. He lo to Christof for confirmation, his finger poised over an “EMERGENCY” button. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (enraged) I said, “Cut!” Christof lunges forward and presses the button himself. T scene in Truman’s bedroom playing on the on-air monitor i abruptly replaced by the “TRUMAN” logo and the message, “TECHNICAL FAULT. PLEASE STAND BY.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TWO OLD WOMEN on the sofa are stunned to see their TV screen go blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEADS also turn in the bar permanently tuned to the "Trum channel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other loyal viewer transfixed by the test card is SYL alone in her darkened apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reminiscent of a military headquarters in wartime, the control room is a scene of barely controlled panic. SECUR GUARDS come and go, phones ring, lights flash, every available VIDEO MIXER is working. The monitors - the “eye of the searchers - are systematically scrutinized for any sign of Truman. CHRISTOF orchestrates operations from his position at the center of the control panel.

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: {nervous) We've declared a curfew. Everyone else is at first positions.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: All prop cars accounted for?

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: He has to be on foot. He has the world’s most recognizable face. He can’t disappear.  130 131 “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 93

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pan down one empty street after another. The town cent totally, eerily deserted. Suddenly, a line of PEOPLE come around the corner, fanned out across the street - a man-h PEOPLE of every description, shoulder to shoulder, marchi down the otherwise empty streets the way a search is conducted at a crime scene. The lines include PRINCIPALS EXTRAS linked arm in arm, wardrobed for their usual roles EXECUTIVES and SECRETARIES, STORE CLERKS, TELEPHONISTS, MAINTENANCE and CONSTRUCTION WORKERS, WAITERS and WAITRES

dialogues.speaker: COOKS, SHOPPERS, HEALTH WORKERS, SECURITY GUARDS, POSTAL
dialogues.text: WORKERS, POLICE OFFICERS, FIRE FIGHTERS and HOMELESS PEOP We occasionally glimpse Truman’s friends and colleagues amongst the searchers - MARLON, LAWRENCE, MOTHER & KIRK, VIVIEN and TYRONE. Even the WASHINGTON’s and SPENCER and PLUTO have joined the search - a snarling Pluto straining the leash has now assumed the role of tracker dog - Truma pajamas waved in front of his nose (clearly miscast as th friendly, neighborhood pooch). : Searchlights from Seahaven's many towers sweep the town. Once, the light falls on a blackened face cowering in the bushes beside a picket fence - the fence now faintly reminiscent of prison bars. Even the beam of the full moo appears to be sweeping the town like a searchlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barriers have been erected at the bridge leading out of Seahaven, guarded by several Seahaven police cars. An extra dressed as a DERELICT wheels his shopping cart towards the bridge. The derelict takes a look along the walkway alongside the bridge as if participating in the search. He finds a POLI OFFICER standing on the walkway.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: Any sign of him?

dialogues.speaker: DERELICT
dialogues.text: (gravelly voice) Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: Take it easy. ~

dialogues.speaker: 131B
dialogues.text: 132 133 134 "THE TRUMAN SHOW" a4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A VIDEO OPERATOR in the sixth row watches the scene on on his monitors - the derelict standing with his back to cam Just as the derelict turns towards camera the Operator tu away to take a sip of coffee. He misses what we see on hi monitor - the derelict's blackened face belongs to TRUMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The disguised TRUMAN heads back to town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTOF turns to a LIGHTING TECHNICIAN.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: We need more light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A building-to-building, floor-to-floor, office-to-office search is also being conducted, each structure secured as they go - the SEARCHERS Paying special attention to poten blind spots such as closets, dumpsters, man holes, sewers car trunks, trees and shrubbery. We focus on one of the waves of searchers. TRUMAN has lin arms in the middle of a row, his disguise still holding u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTOF glances impatiently at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: We'll never find him like this. What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: (anticipating the request) It‘s too early.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter. Cue the sun.  135 136 137 138 139 “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 95

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun instantly rises over Seahaven. CAST and EXTRAS sh their eyes from the sudden glare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While his COLLEAGUES monitor the bank of screens, CHRISTO has been joined by the two anxious studio executives, MOS and ROMAN.

dialogues.speaker: MOSES
dialogues.text: (to Christof who is still studying the faces in a row of

dialogues.speaker: SEARCHERS
dialogues.text: Rumors are circulating he’s dead. The media is in a feeding frenzy. The phone lines are jammed. Every network has a pirated shot of Marlon in the closet.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: {pacing nervously) The sponsors are threatening to rip up their contracts.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (unconcerned, referring to the static “STAND BY” graphic, now accompanied by soothing classical music) Why? We’re getting higher ratings for that graphic than any time in the show's history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The television above the bar carries the test card. PATRO animatedly discuss Truman's fate over their drinks. Some place bets with each other on Truman’s fate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CROWD of passersby hover around a display of television the window of an electronics store, awaiting developments

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fan of EXTRAS reaches the harbor and automatically tu to make another sweep. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: (referring to the empty streets) When we flush him out how do we explain this?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (deadpan) We tell him the truth. CHLOE looks askance at CHRISTOF.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (joking darkly) We're making a movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMAN has broken away from the line of SEARCHERS. However, as he bypasses the entrance to a ticket box, he hasn‘t bargained on coming face to face with another straggler from the search. MARLON. Truman freezes in front of his childhood companio Marion instantly seeing through Truman’s homeless disguis Truman glances nervously in the direction of the searcher Their backs to the two men, they are beginning their next sweep. One shout from Marlon will give Truman away - he i at Marlon’s mercy. Without a word, Marlon walks past Truman and rejoins the Truman glances back to Marlon’s retreating figure but Mar never looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMAN reaches the edge of the dock. He looks out over th bay. There, riding at anchor some two hundred yards out, a sail boat - the same boat that circled Kirk and Truman' sail boat many years earlier. We see a close up of Truman’s terrified eyes in his black face, staring down at the lapping water. He steels himsel shuts out the doubts and dives into the water.  142 143 “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 97

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: (hopeful) I’m sure we'll get him on this next sweep.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (distracted) What have we missed?

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: It’s just a matter of time. CHRISTOF concentrates on a monitor displaying a view of the harbor.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (to Simeon} We’re not watching the sea.

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: (confused) Why would we--

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Sweep the harbor. His COLLEAGUES begin to flick through dozens of waterborn hidden camera shots - in moored craft, lighthouses and bu - trying to locate Truman. Suddenly on one of the monitors there appears a single sa etched against the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: That’s got to be him!

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: How can he sail?! He’s in insurance!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Resume transmission. Simeon punches a button and the image of the sail boat is instantly transferred to the large ON-AIR Monitor. INT. OLD WOMEN’S APARTMENT. NIGHT. 143 The TWO OLD WOMEN doze against each other on the sofa in front of the Tv. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The classical music on the television is abruptly replace the sound of the wind and the sea. One Old Lady blinks he eyes open, her breath taken away by the sight of Truman a the wheel of the sail boat. She rouses her companion.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (staring intently at the ON-AIR monitor) What do we have on that boat? SIMEON scans a computer shot list. He types in a code. A camera from the mast of Truman’s sail boat activates. T unaware of the camera, is concentrating on his sailing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now the ocean spray has washed most of the dirt from TRUMAN’s face - only a residue remains. The rags he wears are soaked. As he steers, he occasionally refers to a “HOW TO SAIL” b from his coat pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MAN in the bath we have seen earlier continues to wat from his tub.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (to himself) I knew he wasn’t dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMAN is at the wheel of the sail boat, wind filling her Seahaven left far behind, his is the only craft afloat in harbor. He sets a course for the open sea as he and his father did long ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTOF and the other PRODUCTION STAFF watch TRUMAN from buoy’s POV as he sails by. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Get another boat.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: The ferry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 149 150 151 A PRODUCTION ASSISTANT runs down the dock towards the FER CAPTAIN and his CREW.

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCTION ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Get that boat out there!

dialogues.speaker: FERRY CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: (who also played the bus driver) I don't know how. We were just told to put on these clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sea choppier now, rising and falling steeply beneath boat, TRUMAN nears a large buoy bobbing clumsily in the strong swell. An official-looking sign on the buoy reads “DANGEROUS WATERS. DO NOT ENTER.” We see an extreme close up of the nautical signpost where a disguised miniature camera tracks Truman's progress.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN
dialogues.text: (anxious) How do we stop him?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (glancing to Simeon) How else? Christof nods to controls on the mixing desk marked, “WIN and “RAIN”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Storm clouds roll towards TRUMAN’s boat at an alarming sp He looks back towards the Seahaven skyline, rapidly reced behind him. Doubts invade Truman's head but he shuts them out and steers into the teeth of the storm - a look of resolve in his eyes we have never witnessed before.  152 153

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 152 MOSES and ROMAN pace at the back of the control room. CHRISTOF is focused on his monitor. Like Truman, he steel himself for a fight.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Cue misic...

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: (hesitant) What music?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (irritated) Storm music...Wagner...

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: (watching the monitor) There's no rescue boat in the area. He won’t know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: MOSES
dialogues.text: (trying to appeal to Christof’s sense of reason) For God’s sake, Chris. The whole world is watching. We can’t let him die in front of a live audience.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: He was born in front of a live audience. (never taking his eyes from the screen) Don‘t worry, he’s not willing to risk his life. His doubts will turn him back. Simeon reluctantly winds the controls for “WAVE”, “WIND” “RAIN” towards their maximum settings.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Kill the lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness suddenly descends. High winds and horizontal driving rain buffet the boat. TRUMAN fights the tiller. Hurricane force winds shake the mast and keel, ripping th sails to shreds. Suddenly, the mast of Truman's boat is struck by a bolt o lightning - snapping the rigging and knocking Truman overboard. Flailing in the tempest, Truman manages to gra (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 153 154 “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 101

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: hold of a trailing rope from the mast and hand-over-hand Grags himself back on board. Truman takes the rope and lashes himself to the wheel. Monstrous waves continually submerge the boat. With what little is left of his rigging, Truman continues to head i the gale.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (shouting above the storm, screaming up to the sky) Come on, is that the best you can do? You're gonna have to kill me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In contrast to his panic-striken COLLEAGUES, CHRISTOF giv an outward appearance of calm. Only we witness the minute bead of sweat appearing at his temple that betrays him.

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: (shocked at the sight of Truman binding himself to the boat) Is he out of his mind?

dialogues.speaker: MOSES
dialogues.text: {to Christof) On behalf of the studio, I demand that you cease transmission.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (defiant, to Operators) Keep running!

dialogues.speaker: MOSES
dialogues.text: --That's not for you to say.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: I take full responsibility--

dialogues.speaker: MOSES
dialogues.text: --I'm telling you for the last time.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (to OPERATOR in front of radar-style screen) How close is he?

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR
dialogues.text: Very close. . (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Capsize him! Tip him over!

dialogues.speaker: MOSES
dialogues.text: (overlapping) For God‘s sake, Christof!

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: (unable to contain herself any longer, entreating Christof) You can‘t! He’s tied himself to the boat. He’ll drown!

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: (staring at Truman on the monitor, becoming affected by his display of courage) He doesn’t care.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: {enraged, to the Operators) Do it! All eyes turn in Christof’s direction. None of the Operat is willing to touch the controls. Christof reaches to the panel and does it himself, turnin the "WAVE" controls to their maximum settings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of giant breakers march in formation across the ~ arising from an unseen source.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waves break across Truman's vessel. TRUMAN appears to losing his fight against the storm, each successive wave taking its toll on his body, sapping his strength, his bindings the only thing keeping him upright. His head slumps, the tiller goes loose in his grasp, rocking out o control. Truman’s will is draining away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The control room CREW watch the heroic image of Truman on ON-AIR monitor, awestruck, as if they too are now spectat watching a movie.  157 158 159

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he is about to be overcome by the next wave, TRUMAN clamps the wheel with his whole body and braces for one last wave. But the wave does not come. A strange phenomenon is occurring in the ocean. A distinct division has appeared the ocean swell. Between the large rolling waves lies a corridor of calmer water, several hundred yards wide, a curious escape lane. The wind and the rain are also subsiding, the darkness lifting. A mist clings to the surface of the water. Truman steers his sail boat down th eerie corridor. Several large, dark shapes emerge on the horizon. Land? Islands? The shapes, containing some enormous mechanism including a huge wheel, only half exposed above water lev appear to be the source of the peculiar wave formations. Truman continues to steer his wrecked sailboat towards th infinitely receding horizon. All is calm until we see the bow of the boat suddenly strike a huge, blue wall, knocki Truman off his feet. Truman recovers and clambers across deck to the bow of the boat. Looming above him out of the sea is a cyclorama of colossal dimensions. The sky he has been sailing towards is nothing but a painted backdrop. Truman looks upward, straining his eyes to see the top of sky, but it curves away at a steep angle beyond his sight Clinging to the boat with one hand, he tentatively reache out towards the painted cyclorama. He touches the sky. He looks about him and simply laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTOF and his PRODUCTION STAFF take in Truman’s reacti in stunned silence.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. BARROOM/LAUNDROMAT/, STOREFRONT/. APARTMENT. NIG
dialogues.text: Truman's laugh echoes around bars, offices, shops, homes streets - wherever a television is to be found - no VIEWE speaks. They too are stunned into a hushed expectancy. Th collective audience holds its breath.  160 161 162 “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 104

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the boat drifts alongside the seemingly never-ending c of the cyclorama, TRUMAN’s attention is drawn to an outli in the otherwise flawless backdrop. He retrieves the identikit picture of Sylvia from his coat pocket and clam to the prow of the boat. There, camouflaged in the painted skyscape just above the water line, is a door. Truman grabs hold of the recessed doorhandle and halts the drifting boat. He stands in fron of the door and closes his eyes in a silent prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The control room CREW stare in silence at the monitor - t very livelihood on the brink of vanishing. CHRISTOF opens small panel on his desk, breaks a seal, and speaks into t emergency P.A. system that is linked to the entire studio

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Truman!

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. OCEAN/CYCLORAMA. DAY. 162
dialogues.text: CHRISTOF’s voice booms over the now calm ocean.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Truman! TRUMAN drops the handle as if his hand has been burned. H looks all about him.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: You can speak. I can hear you. Truman takes a moment to overcome his fear and astonishme

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: I’m the creator. Truman looks up to the “heavens”.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: The creator of what? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 105

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: A show - that gives hope and joy and inspiration to millions.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: {incredulous) A show. Then who am I?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: You're the star. Truman struggles to take it all in.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Nothing was real.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: You were real. That's what made you so good to watch. Truman takes out the drenched picture of Sylvia, recallin her words at the beach.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (to himself) "The eyes are everywhere.°

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTOF picks up a slim, flat monitor. He swivels in his chair and gazes intently at the image of Truman he now ho his hands.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Listen to me, Truman-- On the screen, Truman again reaches for the door handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We focus on TRUMAN's hand. CHRISTOF's voice echoes across the water.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: You can leave if you want. I won't try to stop you. But you won't survive out there. You don't know what to do, where to go. A wave of doubt washes over Truman's face. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 106

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (referring to the photo) I have a map.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Truman, I've watched you your whole life. I saw you take your first step, your first word, your first kiss. I know you better than you know yourself. You're not going to walk out that door--

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: --You never had a camera in my head.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. VARIOUS LOCATIONS. NIGHT. 165
dialogues.text: The VIEWERS stare into camera in fascination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMAN turns back to the sky, looking up towards CHRISTOF

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: Truman, there’s no more truth out there than in the world I created for you ~ the same lies and deceit. But in my world you have nothing to fear. Truman seems to be considering the possibilities. He look to the identikit picture of Sylvia in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOF
dialogues.text: (suddenly angry) Say something, damn it! You're still on camera, live to the world...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SYLVIA gazes at the picture of herself on her television screen as if it is her reflection in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRUMAN opens the door in the sky. He hesitates. Perhaps he cannot go through with it after all. The camera slowly zooms into Truman's face. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 168 169 170 i171 “THE TRUMAN SHOW" 107

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In case I don't see you--good afternoon, good evening and good night. He steps through the door and is gone. Silence. Then -

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. VIEWERS. NIGHT. 169
dialogues.text: Spontaneous jubilation from VIEWERS in their various loca - bars, homes and offices. We follow the figure of SYLVIA running through the streets. Some of the viewers outside electronics store glimpse her as she runs by.

dialogues.speaker: INT, CONTROL ROOM. NIGHT. 170
dialogues.text: Even the cynical SIMEON jumps out of his seat - for the f time in the film - and lets out a joyous whoop, forgettin himself for a moment, caught up in the drama.

dialogues.speaker: SIMEON
dialogues.text: Yes! Self-conscious, he takes his seat again almost immediatel His COLLEAGUES are transfixed by the live ON-AIR monitor continuing to play its only available shot, the open door the sky. Gradually, the attention of those in the control room shi from the monitor to CHRISTOF. He sits slumped, staring at the open door in the sky. Eventually MOSES looks to Simeon. Moses nods to the ‘ON A button. Simeon presses the button and the screen - the mo screen - goes to static.

dialogues.speaker: /END TITLES. 171
